Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: The Mecca Caravan.
div.p: The caravan for Mecca will leave Cairo on about the 25th of December this year.

div.head: Stores for Khaatoum.
div.p: Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi bave been making enquiries for business premises in Khartoum. It is believed that they intend to start a branch store at that city.
National Hotel
The National Hotel, Cairo, opened for the season yesterday, and there are already a fair number of visitors resident there. H.E. Zambao Pashs was one of the first arrivals.
Native Tribunal

The rumour to the effect that the Government has decided to appoint Judges of the Native Tribunals to the administrative post or Mudirs and sub Mudirs, is, we are informed, entirely without foundation.
Maria Theresa Dollars.

The tender of the Union Bank at Trieste for the supply of 44,000 Maria Theresa dollars has been accepted by the Ministry of Finance at the rate of ninety nine milliemes per talari. There were four tenders.
Mohammed All Industrial School

The Mohamed Ali Industrial School at Alexandria will be inaugurated by the Khedive about the end of the current month. There will be a great gathering of members of the Khedivial family, ministers, high fanctionaries and distinguished notables
Bubonic Plague

There have been no cases of plague reported during the last 24 hours, from the 1st of January of this year there have been 1907 cases under trestment in Egypt, of which 842 have proved fatal, there are four eases under en treatment at the present time.
First Aid

The first of a course of six lectures on first for aid to the injured will be given by Mr. A. do Webb Jones, F.R CS, at the Sailors' and by Soldiers' Institute at 8.30 o'clock this evening. These lectures in connection with the St. To John's Ambulance Association will be cortinned of on the first and third Monday in each month.
Lellet ol Kadr.

On Saturday night at 8 o'clock the Khedive and Ghazi Mouhktar Pasha arrived at the the mosque of Abu El Abbas el Morsy with the Governor of Alexandria, Mustafa Pasha Ibadi, the and Ismail Bey Hassanane, the head-master of enl! Ras el Tin sehools, Mohammed Bey Hafiz, insbot pector of the Post Office, Ibrahim Bey El Arab, and other notables. Sheikh Mohamed Rachid Imam el Maieb el Sanieh read the Surat el Kadr.
Theft from a Chapel

Yesterday morning a silver gilt communion chalice of the Roman Catholic cemetery chapel, insi to the value of some £5, was stolen. Immediately mos on discovery of the theft the police were put on and the track and effected not only the arrest of util two susppets, one of whom was Italian and the I T other Greek, but also recovered the cup, which, the however, bad been broken up by the thieves.or al their receivers, and bad therefore lost all sa ve Area its intrinsic value The chalice is now known mer! to bave passed brough three goldsmiths' hands, exhil the arrest of one of whom has been effected as a and recipient of stolen property. very al fe
Egypt's Ancient Races

Professor Flinders Petrie, in his fourth lecture on Babylonia and Egypt, delivered at Uni- the versity College, dealt with the various races lent. and the character of their art. In Egypt, heed th said, there could be traced five races in early the times. They were: (1) The Libyo-Amorite, the which extended through from Algiers to Sy. Salva ris, and formed the main prehistorie people of mark Egypt; (2) a North Syrian type; (3) * peo which ple probably from the eastern mountains: Prine (4) a coast people like the early Greeks ; (5) the p the conquerine Tace which founded the historic age.
Islamic Converts.

The conversion of Copts and Europeans to Islam is frequently annonnced in the local Press and the numbers of such converts in the provincial towns must be considerably more than those whore change of religion is announced, owing to the formalities having been gone throngh at the Cairo or Alexandria Gouvernorats. The latest statisties of the converts from Islam to Christianity are not satisfactory from a missionary point of view. Twenty adult Mahommedans were baptised in the Church Missionary Society's Persia Mission during the years 1896 1900, and in the six years which have since passed 119 adults, besides a number of children have been baptised in that mission. In Egypt the missionaries were gladdened last year by six adults openly confessing Christianity.
Rumoured Appointments

It is said that the Government intend to lent. appoint a successor to Sir Massie Blomfield plants from England. The Cairo newspapers are congra fall of rumours as to this appointment be sho and a contemporary states that the prob- hoya able successor of the Admiral will be either with Chitty Bey or Hunter Pasha. Meanwhile anocher Munier Cairo contemporary given currency to theramourables a that Corbett Bey, the Procureur General ex which pressed a wish to retire on pension, but was year, persuaded by the British Ageney to remain in The his post for the present. The object of the Tramon A geney it is stated, is to gain time in order to The consider the advisability of replacing Corbett names Bey by a native, in accordance with the new policy inaugurated by Sir Eldon Gort.

div.head: HORTICULTURE IN EGYPT. SATURDAY'S CHRYSANTHEMUM SHOW. SPLENDID COLLECTION OF PLANTS.
div.p: Worshippers at Nature's shrine were offered a rare treat on Saturday and yesterday at San Stefano Casino by the Alexandria Hortion tural Society, under whose auspices was held or the on those days the tenth crysanthemum show. a fair Throughout the existence of the society no ambac finer show of the autumn queen of beauty has been held, and we can also assert that no better collection of plants has ever been ex hibited in Egypt. The exhibition must, overn- indeed, have been most gratifying to the comof the mittee, and especially to the energetio secre host ot tary of the society, Mr. D. Fish, who doring med, his first year of office has worked most zealously for the promotion of borticulture in Alexandria. Each successive show bears evi denon of the continual progress made by the "rieste Society and the great improvement effected ollars in the value of the plants and flowers exhibit manceed, thanks to the society's beneficial influence Calari. and the enthusiastie interest of its active members. The marked improvement in the growthis of native gardeners is especially meritorious as illustrative of the excellent Alex work the society is doing edive by educating them in the difficult science of horticulture, There Prior to the formation of the Alexandria the Horticultural Society the possibilities of flower cultivation in this town were unconsidered, but little by little the society has extended its influence and taught master and gardener alike that the field before them is almost unlimited. Every exhibition shows keener 1907 competion and clearly demonstrates that the 842 heathful rivalry between the exhibiting garden.fo der ers greatly promotes the educational efforts of the society,

The attendance on both Saturday and Sunday at the show was good, though on the first former day the number of visitors was un A doubtedly affected by the special regatta beld and by the Khedivial Yacht Club in honour of the ning. I visit of the Khedive. Prince Omar Pasha St. Toussoun, however, was present at the opening aned of the show and heartily congratulated the mth. committee on its excellence, His Highness fix spoke in glowing terms of the high quality of for the exhibits, and the great taste shown in the rep Khe-grading of colours and the general staging of Co the the plants. He remarked upon the strides sit the made by the society since its inauguration and At adi, the wonderful improvement effected in the Sai of eultivation of chrysanthemums, of which he is ope ins both an ardent lover and competent judge.

The show was favoured by excellent weather. I mi med but, in order to guard against the injurious Fre the effects upon the plants of the sea breeze, it lege was fonnd necessary to shelter them by tent. It ing in the lower part of the termce. Needless fast to say, such an arrangement detracts from the I just ion general effect of the exhibits owing to the difal fnsion of the light, but it is hoped that next year whe mely movable glass partitions will avoid this defect, the on and, morever, greatly add to the general the t of utility of the casino dering the winter months.

The most important groups of tradhow were brin ch, the four competing for the medals of the Roy.exel or Al Horticultural Society, which covered an scom ave Area of nearly 3,000 square feet. Almost equal seed mun merit was shown by the four competitors, whose Mol exhibits were without exception excellent, som and the adjudication of the medals proved a half very hard task for the judges. The silver med and al fell to Mr. Zervudachi, whose group was staged with excellent effect and included sever who Bolal varieties of plants hitherto unseen in Egypt: assis i- the plants were dwarf and their culture excel-retal es lent. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun, who grin- putt heed the silver medal staged a very fine selection, Thre ly the quality of each, flower being very fine, though whic e, the stems were rather too long and Mr. Colle y Salvago and Agop Bey Bartau gained equal Aro of marks for the bronze medal with collections furth which lost to the Prince by a very few points and : Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun also obtained Mille 5) the prize for the best chrysanthemum in the yard. show a perfectly cultured white Japanese. they Mr. C. M. Salvage and Agop Bey Bartau were lift also the exhibitors of other large collections, ont the former of whom staged several well-grown dra specimens of the attractive "Phylanthus winn a nivous. last

This species of chrysanthenom which was in anfor troduced into Alexandria a few years ago by defen Mr. Salvago has proved to be one of the most an op useful shrubs for our climate and, as such, ising. deserving of a mach wider cultivation in Egypt. the by The young leaves of the plant have delicate winne I shades of pink and white, which with Age The become green and white. The groups of 75 to betwe 100 also showed an excellence of culturel monti hitherto unachieved, and their staging was forwa! thoroughly effective, the exhibition of Baron de Menasce especially meriting the prize awarded to it.

The Municipality staged a magnificent collection of plants (hors concours), and these occupied a large space near the balcony of the terrace. The group included several standard plants and the general effect was most excel lent. To Mr. Monfront, under whose care the RE planta bave been grown, we offer our hearty congratulations on the recommendation that be should be accorded the silver medal of the Royal Horticultural Wociety, London, together with the thanks of the committee to the Municipality. An excellent exhibition of veget ables and fruits, illustrative of the large variety which can be obtained at this season of the year, was presented by Agop Bey Bartau.
The judges were Messrs. Ebell, Lambotte, Tramontina, Miss Hewat and Mrs. Ruffer.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: VICTORIA COLLEGE F. C. v. ST. ANDREW F.C.

These teams opened their new season's ess fixtures on Saturday last on the ground of the chil of former. Neither side, unfortunately, was the the representative of its full playing strength, I doe of College being withont Saba, Verney, and A. Hes Mustard, and Saints without Curtis, Keill, for Atwood and Mace. College won the toss and he Saints kicked off against wind sad sun. The ful opening was sensational, Saints forwards taking the ball down the field and scoring in the first per er, minute of the game, through MacMillan, men us From the re-start the College almost gained the the it equaliser in similar fashion but Clark relieved. lit thi mt. It was seen that the game was going to be him es fast one, both goals being visited in turn Saints for he just missed making their total two, Jones, after ifa beautiful run putting the ball too far aheadgit ar when favourably set for shooting, with only drap et, the custodian to beat. College now took up figen al the attack and a clever piece of forward play Wool as resulted in Morrison beating Stillgo and thus artis re bringing the teams once inore level Lively the y exchanges ensued until half time but no further stud an scoring took place. From the start of the al second half College were the aggressors, and se Mohsen had a commendable tay. Saints were t, some time in getting over midfield, but this a half very soon gave evidence of being as close and exciting as the first ball. Success again case, came the way of College through Morrison, who was playing a sterling game, being ably | comp t; assisted by Mohsen and Mustard Saints would 1. retaliated in spirited fubion, Morrison putting in some good work on the right wing. stand Three successive corners fell to Saints, all of This b) which were well placed by Morrison but rele College ultimately cleared through Mostard. A run by the college front line looked like As is further increasing their lead, but Clark cleared Egypt and the forwards getting possession Mae H Millan equalised for Saints from the twelve of the yards line. Another splendid opening came the way of Saints but Talloch missed badly. lifting the ball over the bat from two yards out. The game now looked like ending in draw both defences playing op soundly. The winning goal, bowever, came to College in the Nordd last minute of the match, through one of those unfortunate misunderstandings between the Court defending backs which leaves a forward with Hartw an open chance to distinguisb himself by scor mison ing. Morrison saw his opportunity and netted well, the ball, thus enabling College to run out Winners by 3 goals to 2. Sir known The game was one of the fastest ever played station between these two teams, and it is worthy of ment. mention, as showing the combination of the forward lines of both sides that all five goals the M were scored by the centre forwards.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL NOTES.
div.p: THE DATTARI COLLECTION AT CAIRO

In the last issued number of the "Revue Archéologique" one of the most attractive articles was that upon a marble group in the Dattari collection at Cairo. An excellent photo Prize. gravure is supplied and the antiquarian des 1. 40, cription is by Mr. H. Seymour de Ricci of arded Paris. The group, or rather cluster, of figures comes from Dear Memphis and was found there in ery at 1905. It is carved ont of one single block of white marble. Unfortunately the Hachi. central, and considerably the larger and grander, figure, that of Aphrodite, has lost the head and the greater part of both anos. The attitude of the goddess however is so well know from other representations of Antiquity that Baron the statue may be affirmatively assigned as an Aphrodite Anadiomene, that is to say that she is standing with the excess of weight apon the left foot and with both hands wringing the moisture from her tresses prize having just risen from the water. One of the and most beautiful replions of the style of AphroLeo dite statue is the Staart Wellees statuette preserved in London : but also emapating pur). from Egypt, having been aequiredat Minieh. The asce other figures in the Dattari sculpture are a - T. smaller figure of Aphrodite in almost precisely similar pse. Why the artist arranged this Ist duplicate of the Goddess is a mystery. It also is of very inferior execution to the larger and Ban more majestie one. As the miniature statuette had to remain attached in the marble to the rize right leg of the larger one, the artist did not Mr. wish the flesh of both to be in juxtoposition, so a piece of drapery covers the leg of the larger figure below the knee leaving only the ankle anal and foot exposed. Bat, it hangs in an, impossibal ssefble position and shows the lack of ability of 2nd the soulptor. The other side of the group is a Mr. carving of two children embracing, delineated in similar style to the admirable work in the el Capitol Museum at Rome. The pretty attitude of the boy in the and Capitoline example, whose hand seeks to open the lips of the little girl to impress a kiss thereon is not attempted by the Memphite copyist; and in this he follows most replicas of the pair. Curiously enough the size of the the children's group is much larger than thatof the smaller Aphrodite and so the whole piece ro th, does not balance in any way This renders it lor A extremely difficult to suggest any raison d'être for the whole work But Mr. de Rieci anggests one which a care was be ful survey of the piece confirms as being probably correet. That is that the soulptor, mad perbaps a student, and proof of his advance the ment in his art was at some examination given T the piece of marble and ordered to execute in d it the figures that he felt it would best permit jetty him to render, stilising much of the block for the purpose as possible. ticul Most likely the work had to be executed in In dla given time, hence the leaving of a piece of coas drapery, or garment, between two of the in fin figures where the rounding off of the limbs would have closed much delay. The young sente artist doubtless selected the Aphrodite and them the group of the child lovers because in the ure a studio he had executed separate replicas of every these and so he could recarve them with more accuracy and rapidity and because he had to of m work in as much of the block as possible, varied their dimensions to suit the size of the piece of kindn marble. That this, the correct view of the of the case, is substantiated by the back of the scalption, tore being almost as carefully carved and and completed as is the front, which probably it! would not have been if merely intended for BRIT sale to some bourgeois amateur collector to stand upon a shelf in his home, or in a cabinet. matel This hypothesis adds much interest to the from relie and renders it an important piece, for the reproduction in any work upon ancient statuary. ISTO As is classic literature, so in art, it is again to at bo Bgypt that the cultured world is indebted for Mr. B preserving for us the most precious treasures of the past W.L H. W

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Baron and Baroness de Gaiffier d'Hestroy arrived at Alexandria this morning by the J. 0. Norddeutscher Lloyd 8.S. "Hohenzollern."
A decree was granted in the Divorce Court on Monday last on the petition of Lady Hartwell (née Pilon-Fleury) by reason of the misonnduct of ber husband, Sir Brodrick Hartwell, with Mrs. Chamberlain.
Sir Brodrick and Lady Hartwell were well known at Alexandrin, when the former was stationed here with the Leicestershire Regiment.
Among those who arrived this morning by the Moss liner "Menes" were Mr. and Mrs Manball Stewart, Major and Mrs. Pringle, W. Bro Mrs. Walter F. and Master Serieant, Mr. H. P. C. S E. Mann.

The Norddeutscher Lloyd's S.S. "Hobenzollern" on arriving off Alexandria this morning was observed to fly ber flag half mast high. The On Quarantine authorities ordered the steamer to present 1 proceed to Mex where she is still waiting. The cap) an passenger who died was one of the widows of the late Khedive Ismail Pasba.
Finally, M. Lecomte said this was the first and last time he wonld speak of this painful affair. "I am not one of those who fight their political adversaries by sullying their private life."
Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Moss arrived at Alex The andria this morning by the 88. "Habsburg"

Among those arrived this morning by the with pa S.S. "Habsburg" were Mr. Achillopoulo, Mr. The Cornish, Chatsway Bey, Mr. Dilbergon, Miss Doon fr Parnall, Mr. Penderl, Mr. and Mrs. de Galetti, with ge Harari Pasha, Mr. Hersbruch, Dr. Hess Count The de Koziebrodzki, Mr. Parker, Mr. Sinadino, 6th inst Mrs, and the Misses Vivante.

The annual visit of his Highness the Khedive to the Yacht Club on Saturday was attended as usual with immense success. found The wind and weather were everything that single could be desired and suited both the sailing the and the rowing. At about noon all Government vessels in the harbour "dressed ship amongst the others those of the Coastguard, the "Mabrous - The s," "Aida" ete. All of the races both of the sailing and the iece rowing were the best contested we have seen for some time, more partioularly the latter. In the Pairs race all the boats crossed the line etre in a bunch and in the fours a fierce struggleda was witnessed during the last few hundredet yards. Unfortunately the second boat (German) eing tor, made a bad start due to not hearing or seeing bli the starter's pistol, which is regrettable. There was great excitement amongst the cas ven members of the towing clubs, who crowded the mit jetty when the rowing boats houe in sight, and cheered, shouted, and waved their caps, parme ticularly those of the winning boats. In the six-oared galleys race the towers of the sen coastguard training ship "Dib el-Bahr" came de in first, the "Mahroussa's" boat being second. At the close of the races his Highness pre- tion sented the eups to the winners, congratulating them on their success. He expressed his plens-mèt ure at all be had seen and wished the Club en every sucoess in the fatore The Egyptian Army band played selections nou of music during the afternoon. div.head: LA PROPRIETE URBAINE EN EGYPTE
div.p: Nous croyons faire plaisir à nos lecteurs en publiant la conclusion d'une brochure très documentée que le Dr. Alfred Eid vient de faire paraltre sur ce sujet; la voici in extenso:

Sauf pour les terrains de la troisième catégo rie (comprenant les terrains éloignés, situés en dehors de tout mouvement) la situation est saine, les prix qu'ils ont atteints sont justifiés, si l'on fait abstraction de quelques prix payés en pleine effervescence et qui ne sont pas as sez nombreux pour avoir une influence sur l'ensemble de la fortune urbaine. Les différents facteurs de l'évolution que nous avons étudiés continueront leur œuvre et contribueront en core dans l'avenir au développement des villes égyptiennes.

Comment se fait-il qu'un malaise général se soit emparé des spéculateurs et propriétaires, malaise qui peut dégénérer en vraie crise? La cause de ce malaise est dans la rapidité même de l'évolution. Nous venons d'exposer comment les propriétaires ont acheté, en prévision de be- soins toujours grandissants, des terrains bien plus nombreux que ceux qu'ils pouvaient con- vrir de constructions. C'était déjà s'exposer à un grand danger que de laisser ainsi des capi- taux considérables sans revenu immédiat; et ce danger fut encore aggravé par les nombreux achats à tempérament de terrains sans rapport.

Une dette très lourde fut ainsi constituée ans rentrées suffisantes pour en couvrir les charges; au moindre resserrement du crédit cette dette devra peser de tout son poids sur les détenteurs actuels des terrains, ébranler leur situation et arrêter toute transaction nou- velle.

Cependant cette dette a été beaucoup exa- gérée ces temps derniers ainsi que l'étendue des transactions urbaines; comme il arrive toujours en pareil cas, un revirement de l'opi- nion publique s'est produit, arrêtant bon nom- bre de gens qui auraient pu contribuer efficace ment à maintenir la situation. Oubliant l'en- gouement de naguère on s'effraya du rayon énorme sur lequel s'étaient étendus les achats, sans songer qu'une grande partie des terrains compris dans ce rayon devra rester à l'état actuel et que les terrains achetés au loin sont destinés à former des flots d'habitation sépa rés, entourée de jardins et de terrains maral- chers pour lesquels il n'y a pas lieu de penser d'ici très longtemps encore à la destination urbaine. Ces flots ne doivent certainement pas être considérés comme une continuation de la ville.

Nous ne pouvons done aller plus loin avant d'avoir dégagé la valeur réelle des acquisitions et de la dette qui en est résultée. Malheureu- sement, ce sont là des données difficiles à éta- blir, vu le grand nombre de personnes qui ont pris part à ces affaires et le peu de publicité de ces dernières. Aussi nos résultats ne peuvent- ils être que très approximatifs.

An Caire et dans ses environs les lotisse ments et achats nouveaux forment une surface de 9 millions de mètres carrés environ repré- sentant une valeur d'achat, tous frais compris, de 6 millions de liv. ég. et une valeur de re- vente de 12 millions. Ces différentes transac tions se répartissent comme snit:
1. Quartiers centraux de la ville: 200,000 mètres carrés pour 3 millions de liv. ég, soit en moyenne 15 liv. ég. par metre carré;

2. Lotissements et ventes dans les quartiers nouveaux: Choubrah, Ghézireh, Garden City, etc., compris dans notre évaluation: 1,100,000 mètres carrés ponr 4 millions de liv. ég. soit un peu moins de 4 liv. ég. le mètre carré.

3. Lotissements autour de la ville, com- prenant les nouveaux terrains s'étendant de Konbbeh à Marg, Mahmacha, les lotissements entre Rod el Farag et Choubrah village, Rodab, la rive gauche du Nil et les parcelles loties de Meadi: 7,600,000 mètres carrés pour 5,300,000 liv. ég, soit en moyenne 0.70 liv, ég. le mètre carré.

Les lotissements suburbains n'ont done a- grandi le domaine de la ville, comme nous l'a vons établi, que de 7,600,000 mètres carrés ayant une valeur de vente de 5,300,000 liv.ég.. soit une augmentation de 28 p.e. pour la super- ficie et sealement de 6.4 p.e pour la valeur. Si même toute cette superficie était complè tement perdue pour la construction, le déficit serait petit en comparaison de la valeur globale de la ville. Mais heureusement il n'en est pas ainsi et un tiers au moins de ces terrains, pos- sède déjà tous les éléments d'un développe- ment lent mais continu.

L'unique indication nons permettant de nous faire une idée de la dette résultant des tran sactions urbaines, nous est fournie, par les bilans des societés. On compte actuellement en Egypte une quarantaine de sociétés s'ocon- pant d'opérations immobili res; les unes en font leur occupation exelusive, les autres y joignent soit des entreprises agricoles soit des entreprises de constructions et de travanx publics.

Parmi ces sociétés sept ont pour but unique de construire des maisons et de les exploiter directement; elles ont un capital nominal de 844,000 liv. ég. et un capital libéré de 494,000 liv. ég (soit respectivement 21,1 et 12,3 mil- lions de francs). Leur genre d'opérations ne rentre pas dans nos calculs et nous ne les avons mentionnées que pour mémoire.

Nous avons sous les yeux 18 bilans apparte nant aux principales sociétés s'occupant d'opé rations immobilières proprement dites: achat, ventes et lotissements de terrains, soit à l'exe clusion de fout autre entreprise, soit accessoi- rement et qui sont: la Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte, la Delta Land Investment, l'Egyp tian Entreprise and Development, l'Improve ment Corporation, la Cairo Suburban Buil ding, l'Alexandria Central Building, la Nile Land and Agricultural Co., la Société des Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux, la Building Lands of Egypt, la Heliopolis Oases C", la New Egyptian Company, les Egyptian Bata tes, l'Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt, la Compagnie agricole du Nil, la Financial Land
Building Company of Egypt, la Compagnie der Entreprises, urbaines et rurales, l'Esyptian Land Investment Company, les Guezireh Mansions.
La situation financière do 083 - sociétés se présenté comme suit: Capital nominal

4,688,000 o libéré. 4,073,000 Obligations........ 720,000 Réserves diverses... 432,500 Termins et immeubles en compte propre...........! Terrains et Immeubles en partici*cipation ............ Sommes dues par les sociétés sur les achats à terme........... 760,000 Sommes dues aux sociétés sur les ventes à terme.... 2,126,500 Créditeurs divers.................... 1,182,000 Débiteurs divers........................ 249,000

Remarquons cependant que comme tous les bilans ne font pas la distinction entre les créances diverses et les créances sur les ter rains, ni entre les débiteurs pour terrains et les débiteurs divers, il serait plus exact de représenter l'ensemble des créances comme suit : Créances diverses 1,942,000 liv. ég., dont 80 p.c. sur les terrains ; débite ira divers, 2,385,000 liv. ég., dont 90 p.e. pour les terrains.

Nous devons faire une autre remarque pour éclairer le lecteur non prévenu : si les placements de ces sociétés en terrains urbains sont faibles relativement aux ressources, cela est du au fait que beancoup d'entre elles en emploient une partie à d'autres opératiotis.

En dehors de ces sociétés, sur le fonctionnement desquelles nous sommes suffisainment renseignés, il y en a 14 autres de date si recente (quelques-unes seuleme remontent au-delà de 1 an), qu'elles n'ont pas eu le temps de publier des bilans. Ce sont: LA Cominercial Industrial and Land Company, la Cairo Land and Fi nancial Company, l'Epargne > Immobilière" l'Egyptian and Syrian Land Company, la Helouan Development Company, les Koubbeh Gardens, les Cairo Estates, les Cairo Buildings, l'Egyptian Land, I'Investment and Building, les Economical Residences, l'Industrial Building and Cominercial Company of Bgypt, la Compaggie des Biens-Fonds urbains et ruraux, la City and Agricultural Land Company, la Gabbari Land Company. Elle représentent un capital nominal de près de cinq millions de liv. ég, dont la moitié a été versie

Ces sociétés ont acheté pour à peá près 3 millions de liv. ég. de terrains et ont paye comptant environ 1,500,000 liv. ég. Leur peu de durée n'a pas permis de revendre une quan tité bien importante de leurs terrains et l'on peut évaluer ces ventes à 300,000 on 400,000 liv. ég., dont on tiers payé.
Nous résumons l'activité de toutes ces sociétés au point de vue qui nous intéresse comme suit en milliers de Livres Egyptiennes.

SOC.ANC, SOC.NOUV. TOTAL 1° Entièrement payés. 2,800 1,500 4,300 2 Dont le prix est dn 800 1,100 1,900 Valeur totale des terrains disponibles. . . 3.600 2,600-6,200 Sommes dues par les Sociétés. ....... 1,500 Sommes dues aux Soc. 2,000 1,500 300 3,000 5,800 Montant total des créances ...... 3,500 1,800 5,300

En dehors des sociétés anonymes, il y a quel ques sociétés en commandite et de nombreux particuliers qui se sont occupés de ce genre d'affaire L'évaluation de leur charge est plus malaisée encore vu le manque de tout document public. Les renseignements que nous avons pris à des sources privées, nous permet tent de croire toutefois que nous ne sommes pas bien loin de la vérité en estimant l'impor tance de leurs opérations à la moitié de celles des sociétés anonymes.

Nous pouvons donc évaluer l'ensemble des terrains disponibles pour la construction en Egypte à une dizaine de millions de liv. ég: et le montant total des charges provenant des ventsed terme sur la propriété immobilière (terrains vagues et construits) à environ 849 millions de liv. ég. Dans ces charges figurent! les dettes dues par plusieurs aoquéreurs sticces ! sifs pour un même terrain.

De telles charges sont loddes assurément, I néanmoins, sans vouloir atténuer lour gravity il est de notre devoir de montrer que toutes ces charges ne pèsent pas d'un poids mort sur le la propriété urbaine et que même dans l'état actuel une partie des dettes s'éteint petita petit.

Beaucoup de terrains situés dans la ville donnent des revenus permettant A leur acqué. reur de se libérer dans les délais fixés ; d'autres, en transformation, sont déja assurés d'une rentrée suffisante pour le moment on ilx pour. ront recevoir des locataires. Parmi les sociétés et les particuliers ayant entrepris de grands lotissements, la plupart tirent des revenus soit d'entreprises nrbaines en pleia rapport, soit d'entreprises agricoles ou commerciales qui leur permettent de supporter les charges de lenrs terrains invendus et meme la pertu eventuello qu'ils subiront sur les terrains excentriques Ajoutons, en ce qui concerne ces derniers, que les grands lotisseurs les ont achetés souvent des prix tellement bas que les sommes qu'ils out touobées sur les parties revendues couvrent dans une certaine mesam leurs débours et que par conséquent ils pourraient garder improdue tives pendant unsez longtemps les parties invendues.

La situation la plus critique est celle des petits péculatoors qui ont placé leur épargne dans des terrains dépourvus pour le moment de touto valeur et de oeux qui ont fait des su crifices pour spheter des terrains ayant un avonir immédiat mais qui n'ont plus les moyens pour les atitisor de maintenant en les dotant de constructione adéquate

Il fait dono impiter le malaise actuel moins à la spéculation, bien que quelques excée aient provoqué la méfiance, gu'à la stagnation gé. nérale des affaires qui a désorganisé le crédit, a empêché ceux qui en avaient le plus besoin de se procurer des fonds d'exploitation et qui, aggravant les charges existantes, a arrêté tonte affaire nouvolle dans le domaine urbain.

Le remède contre ce mal est tout indique : prolongation. Wes échéances jusqu'à des temps meilleurs, liquidation prudente et successive des positions surchargées, adoption de combinaisons financieras mettant a la portée des propriétaires et des entrepreneurs les sommes nécessaires pour rendre productifs los bons torrains. C'est là une conduite d'autant plus facile à suivre que les sociétés immobilières, in téressées directement ou indirectement dans la plupart des grandes transactions, possèdent les ressources nécessaires pour attendre et même liquider si o'était nécessaire dertaines affaires avec quelques pertes et que d'autre part, les capitaux engagés, non pas dans la sprculation mais dans la construction, ne oourent aucun risque.

Ces mesures peuvent être appelées de bote négatif du programme urbain, elles sont de tinées à relever le crédit, à aplavir les difficultés de l'heure présente. Ensuite il y aura toyl an programme positif à remplir, car on aurait tort | de croire que l'évolution des villes égyptiennes est définitivement arrêtée et qu'il n'y a plus rien Afrire au point de vue immobilier.

Les principaux points de ce programme sont la multiplication de constructions sur les terrains vides des quartiers en plein développe mont; élaboration des combinaisons financières permettant même aux classes moyennes de de venir propriétaires dans la banlieue, création sur certains lotissements existants d'agglomé. rations nouvelles répondant à toutes les exi gences de l'hygiène et accessibles à toutes les | boarses. Ces agglomérations pourront être asi sez éloignées des centres, mais elles doivent être dotées de moyens de communications rapides. C'est un projet d'agglomération de ce genre que la Socisté des Oasis est en train d'exécuter en ce moment.

Une des parties et non la moins intéressante de ce programme est celle ayant trait anx quartiera indigènes et aux villes de province. Nous avons vu combien les quartiers araber du Caire et d'Alexandrie étaient en retard sur le reste de la ville et quelles difficultés s'oppo saient A leur transformation. Mais dès que les pouvoirs publics auront exécuté les grandtravaux d'utilité publique, les entreprises im mobilières qui rénoveront ces quartiers pour ront bien réaliser tout ce qui s'est fait jusqu'aujourd'hui dans les centres.

Les villes de provinces se trouvent un peu dans la situation des quartiers arabes. Elles réunissent tous les éléments nécessaires à leur évolution : angmentation de la prospérité gént. rale, extension des affaires, concentration de la population, changement dans le genre de vie, relations de plus en plas suivies avec la Caire et Alexandrie. Il ne lear manque qu'un encouragement sérieux de la part des autorités, quel ques modifications radicales dans le réseau de leurs rues, la création et le développement de services publics tels que : eau, éclairage, tram ways, et surtout la constitution, pour les villes qui en sont encore privées, de municipalités capables de s'intéresser à leurs besoins pour les voir prendre un essor rapide.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Au point de vue transactionnel la matinée a 'été aussi nulle que les jours précédents, mais on a constaté en général plus de fermeté dans les prix. Les échanges se sont disséminés up I peu sur toute la cote. A signaler senlement de façon particulière les Banques et le Comptoir. Celui-ci, en dépit d'un bilan qui paralt avantageux, a subi une nouvelle dépréciation. Le cours s'inscrit à 2 21/82 l'action et 1 3/4 ex coupon la part de fondateur, en baisse res. pective de 3/32 et 1/8. Les valeurs dirigeantes sont, en revanche, mieux tenues : l'Agricole reprend de 716/16 8, la National Bank de 20 5/8 à 20 7/8, IR Delta Light de 9.7/8 à 10, la Daïra de 12 7/8 4 12 15/16. Seule l'Obligation Crédit Foncier recule de 1 franc à 294 l'ancienne et 253 1/2 la nouvelle. En avance également les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 135 à 136 et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 and 4 1 16. 1 La Banque d'Athènes fêchit, au contraire, de 108 à 107, les Nungovich Hotels de 16 3/4 à 16 5/8, la Nile Land de 9 8 8 1/2, les Splendid Hotels de 4 5/16 41/4, l'Urbaine de 3 3/8 4 3 1/4 et l'Union For cière de 43/4 4 11/16. Parmi les titres diarire secondaire, les Markets progressent de 2 à 27/- ex-coupon. la Delta Land de 1.9/32 and 1 5/16, et In Le yant de 5/16 à 11/32, tandis que la Salt and Soda rétrograde de 17- à 16/ T'Investmont de 3/8 11/32, les Ritz Hotels de 1/2 à 13/32 et l'Helouan de 5/32 A 1/8. La baisse de certaines valeurs chyt motivée par diverses rumeurs mires récemment en circulation. La tendance, quoique plus ferme, est cepen dant ind cise. Il a été vendu aux enchères publiques 50 Karam (Industrial and Building) 1 516, 50 Building Landk à 49/64, 50 Investment (Abdy) 23/64, 50 Estates à 27/64,10 Levant (petits bateaux) 4 1/2, et 200 Langbis à 15/64.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation s'est réunie lo 2 Novembro 1907 a 9 h. da soir sous la présidence de Son Excellence. le Dr. Schiess Pacha. Présentez:- MM. Ahmed Pacha Yehia, L. Escoffier, Mansour Bey Youssef, Amb. A. Ralli, Soliman Boy Abani, membres, I. Sodky Bey, seorétaire général. La Délégation ne croit pas devoir faire droit à une demande de divers requérants tendant and l'installation d'un pont sur le canal Mahmou. dieh reliant les Champe-Elysées avec la rive gauche da canal et offrant de payer à cet effet, à la Municipalité, une redevance annuelle. Une demande ayant été présentée pour la mise en vente de la parcele No. 41 sur les Quais, la Délégation décide de faire évaluer la dite parcelle par le Conseil d'Estimation. | La Délégation charge MM. Ralliet Mansour Bey Youssef d'examiner sur place le bien fonde d'une requête présentée par les sociétés des Presses Libres et les Presses Allemandes, au sujet du dallage de la ruelle longeant leurs établissements et reliant la rue Einani à celle du er Khedive.. A l'occasion d'une demande présentée par on particulier pour l'établissement d'un bain da obté: d'Anfouchy, la Délégation considère que l'octroi de ces sortes de concession devrait faire l'objet d'une mise en adjudication. Sous le bénéfice de cette réserve et après rapprt du comité sp;cial qui avait été chargé d'examiner les emplacemeots qui convien. draient le mieux à l'ibstallation d'un bain dans cette localité, la Délégation renvoie également ootte question à l'étude des services techniques et sanitaires. La Délégation rejette une demande pour la construction d un établissement balnéaire entre | le Camp de César et l'Ibrahimich en raison des travilux de corniche que la Municipalité se propose d'exécuter dans ces parages. Comme suite à une lettre de la Municipalité relative an timbrage de la viande de bufies de provenance étrangère, qui est transportée au Caire, le Ministère de l'Intérieur fait remar quer que l'autorisation du transport de la vian* do d'Alexandrie au Caire directement, sous les conditions déjà établies, est valable seulement pour la viande do b tail provenant de la Roa manje, de la Serbie, de la Bulgarie, de la Bosnie "Het de l'Herzégovine, à l'exclusion de celle pro Wenant de la Syrie et autres pays infectés. La Délégation en prend note. Ello nutorise une dépense de L.E. 40 pour la confection des travaux de macadamisaga en chakt des rues Toussoun a Ramleh, Maamoun et de la rue conduisant au Victoria College. La Délégation ajourne à sa prochaine séance l'examen de deux rapports présentés par le Service Sanitaire proposant la réglementation du transport du lait ainsi que celle des hôtels d'émigrants et de pèlerins. T. La séance est levée à 11 p.m.

div.head: LORD, CROMER'S SPEECH. HOARDING OF GOLD. THE EGYHTIAN SLUMP.

div.p: Lord Cromer, speaking at the Guildball on the 28th October, said that he wished Sir El. don Gorst every success which he was apre he • would achieve it he did not allow himself to be burried by faddists in Eagland and their numerous sympathisera in Egypt who regard London as a sort of political Mecca. Referring to the drain of gold to Egypt he said that this was likely to occur annually as the cotton crop was assured and the country well nigh secured against the vicissitudes of season. This year's-Nile was the lowest on rol cord bat it was probable that the crop would be extremely favourable. Every year some £ 25,000,000 or £30,000,000 have to be found to finance the crop. The most remarkable feature was that al great deal of money going to Egypt never comes baok. During the last four years the imports of gold to Egypt amounted to £13,000,000 more than the exports. It was almost impossible to say what becomes of this vast quantity of coin but it is certain that a great deal is converted into jewellery. • Hoarding of money is carried to an extent Almost incredible to Europeang. He cited instances where large sums, bad been hidden in cellars or buried in gardens. He hoped that the banking facilities would gradually wear the natives of Egypt froin this uncommercial habit. Referring to the slump in Egyptian, under takinge, he did not doubt that some individuals deserving of syınpally had suffered, but he could not think that from a general point of view the recent occurrences were to be regretted. He hoped they would do something to stop. over-speculation which had been very narked and was a very mischievous feature of Egyptian markets of recent years. There were many striking instances of this and it was quite manifest that this period of inflation could not last. The prosperity of the country was in no way suffering the wealth of Egypt was essentially agricultural. He only knew of two risks to which it was exposed: if the demand 1or Egyptian cotton were to diminish, un doubtedly great embarrassment would be caused, but bê knew of no reason for supposing that any such contingencey would arise as the world's demand for cotton was steadily in creasing. The other risk was totally different: the financial prosperity of Egypt undoubtedly depended to a great extent on the policy adopted in Egypt He thought it would be a mistake to take too seriously the proceedings of what are called Egyptian Nationalists or of their friends in Great Britain, inasmuch as some of the latter appeared to him, to mislead Egyptians as to the true trend of public opinion in this country and to encourage the hope that political development would be much more rapid than could be at all possible : lie was accustomed to regard these as the worst eneinies of Egyptian pro. gtese. When he said Egyptian Nationalists he did | not wish to be misunderstood : he was not al. luding to those who favoured a moderatereasonable, and gradual extension of self-govern. ing institutions. These had his entire sympathy and throughoat his career in Egypt he had done his beat to encourage them. Henlluded to the extremists who existed in Cairo, as in Calcutta and Dublin. With these gentlemen he did not think it possible to deal. They could not be conciliated save on terms which in India and Ireland would spell political suicide and in Egypt involve relapse into all the unisgovernment and disorder of the past. At present some of the yonth of India and Egypt appeared to be basing their political conduct on the proceedings of agitators in this - country. He referred in this connection to the almost culpable folly of Mr. Keir Hardie. Lord Cromer saw but one method of dealing with the unrest and disturbances in Egypt and India, namely, to continue steadily to do our duty towards the people and to come down with heavy haud upon exemists, should they overstep, the law, but not to be deterred by their presence or proceedings from adopting reforms calculated to satisfy moderate or reasonable aspirations.. (Reuter)

div.head: GREEKS AND BULGARIANS, RECRUDESCENCE OF ACTIVITY.

div.p: A Greek circular to the Powers in reply to the Austro Rossian note points out that every relaxation of the defensive measures taken by the Greeks in Macedonia is followed by a recrudescence of activity among Bulgarian bands. A similar recrudescence followed the Austro-Russian note. The Powers should seek to eliminate the causes of agitation. The Government hopes that any eventual delimitation will be based upon status quo before the Bulgarians sought to modify the ethnographical conditions by violence In deference to the Powers Greece would continue to do her utrnost to assist in pacifica tion and to tranquilliso the Greeks in Mace. donin, but in order to restore confidence it was necessary to protect the latter and to ASSOTO f them with reference to the future. (Reuter) MOBAstir, November 4. A Greek band attacked a party of Bulgarians in the Florina district, killing 4 and wounding 5 of them. (Renster)

div.head: THE RAILWAY CRISIS. HEAVY STRIKE BALLOT.

div.p: The ballot of the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants-hos resulted in a majority of 78,152 in favour of a strike apless the recognition of the Union is conceded. (Router)

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS. THE DANGER OP CROCODILES.

div.p: 1 Professor Koch, interviewed with regard to the sleeping sickness which is wiping out the population of the Senge group of Islands (Victoria Nyanza), urged the destruction of all crocodiles whose blood constitutes the chief nourishment of the glossina fly. (Reuter)

At the municipal elections which took place in England and Wales yesterday the returns of 141 boroughs show that the Conservatives won 115 seats, Liberal 20. Labourites 22. Independents 4, and Socialists 4. The Socialista where defeated in 27 boroughs where they attempted to displace candidates seeking re. election. (Reuter) LONDON, November 2. Ladies for the first time were candidates for the municipal dlections. Only 4 out of 17 were returned. (Reuter)

150'arrests have been made here amongst soldiers, sailors and civilians. It appears that agitators had long been working among the garrison of sailors to produce a mutiny. The merchantmen steamed out of the barbour betare the firing began. The crew of the des. troyer "Serdity" also mutinied and wounded t the captain and other officers, but a loyal destroyer, with the aid of a detachment of i troops quelled the mutiny. (Reuter)

Conflicting accounts are coming 10 handjof the earthquake at Karatagh It appears that threo successive shocks were felt and afterwards! A mountain slide occurred. The death-roll now varies between 1,500 and 5,000. (Reuter) +

div.head: ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS
div.p: The following animals have been received at the Zoological Gardens during the last two months : Two Springbok Gazella euebore (new to the collection) from South Africa. One Duiker Cephalophus griinmi, from South Africa. One Hussar Monkey Cercopithecus patas (new to the collection), from West Africa Two Baboons Papio anubis, from West Africa. One Palm-Civet Nandinia binotata (new to the collection) from West Africa. One American Rail Aramides ypecaha (new to the collection). Two Chinese Geese Anser cygnoides (now to the collection) Four Burrow Sbeldrakes Tadorna cornuta. All these have been received in exchange from Mr. W. S. Cross, Liverpool, Three Pantherine Toads Bufo mauritanica froin Biskra, Algeria, presented by Miss R. Boughton Leigh. A collection of Snakes from the Province of Giz, including a Horned Viper Cerastes cornutus, purchased. One Block winged Pratincolo Glareola melanoptera (now to the collection), from the Province of Giza, purchased. Collection brought from the Sudan by the Director - Two White-nosed Red Monkeys, Cercopithecus pyrrhonotus. One parohased, and one froin the Tagale Hills, Kordofan, presented by Mr. C, P. Brown. Five young Sudanese Lions, Pelis leo. One Lion and two Lionosses from Singa, presented by Mr. -P. D. Murphy, late R. N. One Lion from Roseires, and one Lioness from Gedaref, porchased. Ore young male Leopard, Felis pardus, presented by Mr. R. H. Woods, both K.R. Rifles. One Genet-Cat, Genetta dongolana, from Kassals, presented by Mr. J. H. Griove One Jackal,Canis sp. incert, from Wad Medani. presented by Anis Bffendi Saad, Mamoor, Wad Medani Prison. One Ground Squirrel, Xerus rutilas, from Roseires. Two magnificent young male Waterbucks Cobus, defassa, from Roseires presented by Mr. L. Gorringe, Inspector, Repression of Sinve Trade Department. A young male Tiang Hartebeest, Bubalis (Damaliscgs) tiang, caught at Sherif HassabulloBlue Nile. This is the first individual of this fine animal, the "Senegal Antelopo" of the late Sir Samuel Baker ("Ismailia," pages 68 and 74), that has been regeived in the Gita Gardens and as far as is known is the first specimen to reach alive any Zoological Garden in the world. Since the reopening of the Sudan, living Tiang have been one of the principal desiderata of the Egyptian colleotion, and this valuable addition has beon made through the kind bolp of Mr. F.D. Marphy. div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN BOLTON.
div.p: The "Pinancier" says :-A quiet, steady business bas of late been done in Egyptian yarns as spun in the Bolton district. Users however, at the moment are not disposed to place contracts of magnitude. Buying, for the most part, seems to be carried or from band to mouth. Speaking generally, producers are in a strong position, especially in the finer numbers of combed descriptions. Users find they have to pay full rates for anything wanted. Certain producers are behind contract time with deliveries, and inconvenience is often caused. Or the whole, this section of our market may be described as the healthiest in the trado. The margin is very good, and the demand koeps up fairly well.
